title: My husband has a judgment against him, can the creditor lien my LLC to cover his judgment?
question: My husbands judgement creditor is making a motion with the court to be able to attach my wage/earnings from my LLC. Can they do this legally?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce by default judgment,Divorce and bankruptcy,LLC (limited liability company),Bankruptcy,Judgment lien,Debt,Wage garnishment,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Default judgment
answers:
Your earnings are probably community property. Therefore, half of your earnings belong to your husband and can be reached by his creditors. Without reviewing the documents, including the papers that the creditor filed (Declaration, Memo of P&As, etc.) and reviewing your LLC documents and earnings history, I cannot give you any more detailed advise. I suggest that you retain an attorney to represent you at the hearing and/or negotiate with the creditor.

PS. If you are separated from your husband, and the debt does not involve necessities of life, your earnings may be safe, pursuant to Family Code section 910 and related statutes.

Unpaid judgment creditors can go after the spouse's accounts to enforce the money judgment. Cal. Code of Civil Procedure, Section 695.020(a), states: "Community property is subject to enforcement of a money judgment as provided in the Family Code.”

Cal. Family Code, Section 910, states: “Except as otherwise expressly provided by statute, the community estate is liable for a debt incurred by either spouse before or during marriage, regardless of which spouse has the management and control of the property and regardless of whether one or both spouses are parties to the debt or to a judgment for the debt.”

Please read my two links, below, to my blog about options if a debt collection lawsuit has resulted in a judgment and my Avvo legal guides explaining how to negotiate such lawsuits (I have a series of three legal guides about settling a debt collection lawsuit). No wage garnishment or bank levy may begin without a judgment for money being awarded first, as to private debts. If there is a default judgment, my recommendation is to consult with an attorney who regularly defends such lawsuits and find out how more reasonable it is to retain such an attorney to help properly resolve the collection case and default judgment and your options.
